# Read the csv file

# Convert 'DateTime' column to datetime type

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Convert the 'DateTime' column to datetime type
df['DateTime'] = pd.to_datetime(df['DateTime'])

# Set the 'DateTime' column as the index
df.set_index('DateTime', inplace=True)

# Resample the data by hour and count the number of items sold
items_sold_per_hour = df['Items'].resample('H').count()

# Create the time series plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
items_sold_per_hour.plot(kind='bar')
plt.title('Item Sales Over the Course of a Day')
plt.xlabel('Time of Day')
plt.ylabel('Number of Items Sold')
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Count the number of each job title by company size
job_title_count = df.groupby(['Company_Size', 'Job_Title']).size().reset_index(name='counts')

# Pivot the data to get the count of each job title by company size
pivoted_df = job_title_count.pivot(index='Job_Title', columns='Company_Size', values='counts').fillna(0)

# Create a bar plot of job titles by company size
pivoted_df.plot(kind='bar', figsize=(10,6))
plt.xlabel('Job Title')
plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.title('Job Titles by Company Size')
plt.legend(title='Company Size')
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Create a figure and axis object
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

# Create a bar plot of free kicks by team
ax.bar(['Team 1', 'Team 2'], [df['free kicks team1'].sum(), df['free kicks team2'].sum()], label='Free Kicks')

# Create a bar plot of penalties scored by team
ax.bar(['Team 1', 'Team 2'], [df['penalties scored team1'].sum(), df['penalties scored team2'].sum()], label='Penalties Scored')

# Set title and labels
ax.set_title('Free Kicks and Penalties Scored by Team')
ax.set_xlabel('Team')
ax.set_ylabel('Count')

# Legend
ax.legend()

# Show the plot
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Create a stacked bar plot of Sleep Disorder by BMI Category
sleep_disorder_counts = df['Sleep Disorder'].value_counts()
bmi_categories = df['BMI Category'].unique()

counts_per_bmi = []
for bmi in bmi_categories:
    counts_per_bmi.append((df[df['BMI Category'] == bmi]['Sleep Disorder'].value_counts()))

behavior_class_counts = [df[(df['Operating System'] == os) & (df['User Behavior Class'] == behavior_class)].shape[0] for os in os_list for behavior_class in behavior_classes]
behavior_class_counts = [behavior_class_counts[i:i+len(behavior_classes)] for i in range(0, len(behavior_class_counts), len(behavior_classes))]

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.tick_params(axis='x', labelrotation=90)
bottom = [0]*len(os_list)
for i, behavior_class in enumerate(behavior_classes):
    ax.bar(os_list, [behavior_class_counts[j][i] for j in range(len(os_list))], bottom=bottom, label=behavior_class)
    bottom = [bottom[j] + behavior_class_counts[j][i] for j in range(len(os_list))]

ax.set_title('User Behavior Class by Operating System')
ax.set_xlabel('Operating System')
ax.set_ylabel('Count')
ax.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Create a pie chart of goal preventions by team
goal_preventions_team1 = df['goal preventions team1'].sum()
goal_preventions_team2 = df['goal preventions team2'].sum()

labels = ['Team 1', 'Team 2']
sizes = [goal_preventions_team1, goal_preventions_team2]
colors = ['gold', 'lightskyblue']
explode = (0.1, 0)  # explode 1st slice

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.pie(sizes, explode=explode, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%',
       shadow=True, startangle=140, colors=colors)

ax.axis('equal')  # Equal aspect ratio ensures that pie is drawn as a circle.

plt.title('Goal Preventions by Team')
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Group by Age and calculate average App Usage Time
avg_app_usage_time_by_age = df.groupby('Age')['App Usage Time (min/day)'].mean().reset_index()

plt.xlabel('Age')
plt.ylabel('Average App Usage Time (min/day)')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Convert the DateTime column to datetime type
df['DateTime'] = pd.to_datetime(df['DateTime'])

# Extract the date part from the DateTime column
df['Date'] = df['DateTime'].dt.date

# Group by Date and count the number of transactions
sales_per_day = df.groupby('Date').size()

# Create a bar plot of total sales per day
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
sales_per_day.plot(kind='bar')
plt.title('Total Sales per Day')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Total Sales')
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Convert 'DateTime' column to datetime type
df['DateTime'] = pd.to_datetime(df['DateTime'])

# Group by 'DateTime' and count 'TransactionNo'
transactions_over_time = df.resample('D', on='DateTime')['TransactionNo'].count()

# Create a line plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(transactions_over_time.index, transactions_over_time.values, marker='o')
plt.title('Transactions Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Number of Transactions')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Group the data by Daypart and Items, and count the number of transactions
df_grouped = df.groupby(['Daypart', 'Items']).size().reset_index(name='Count')

# Pivot the data to create a stacked bar plot
df_pivot = df_grouped.pivot(index='Daypart', columns='Items', values='Count')

# Create the stacked bar plot
df_pivot.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, figsize=(10,6))

# Show the plot
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')

# Create a density plot of GMAT scores by gender
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
for gender in df['gender'].unique():
    gmat_scores = df[df['gender'] == gender]['gmat']
    plt.hist(gmat_scores, density=True, alpha=0.5, label=gender)

plt.xlabel('GMAT Scores')
plt.ylabel('Density')
plt.title('Density Plot of GMAT Scores by Gender')
plt.legend()
plt.show()
